Understates: The claim may understate the potential impact of the proposed cuts by only mentioning the number of people on food stamps and children receiving school lunches or breakfasts. It does not mention any potential negative consequences or hardships that may arise from these cuts.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks specific evidence or data to support the stated numbers of "2 million less people on food stamps" and "210,000 children will not receive school lunches or breakfasts." It does not provide any sources or studies to back up these figures.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the proposed cuts in the House farm bill will directly result in the stated number of people losing food stamps and children losing school lunches or breakfasts. However, it does not consider any alternative factors or potential alternative explanations for these changes.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider any alternative explanations or factors that may contribute to the potential decrease in the number of people on food stamps or children receiving school meals. It solely attributes these changes to the proposed cuts in the House farm bill.
